questions.text: A 60-year-old man collapses at a shopping mall. Bystanders start CPR and activate EMS. On arrival, paramedics find the patient unresponsive, pulseless, and in ventricular fibrillation on the monitor. What is the next best step for his managment?

choices.text: Begin chest compressions and administer 1 mg epinephrine immediately, then attempt defibrillation
Deliver one shock with a biphasic defibrillator followed by immediate chest compressions, then secure airway
Deliver three stacked shocks followed by pulse check and atropine administration
Perform synchronized cardioversion followed by amiodarone if rhythm persists

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Deliver one shock with a biphasic defibrillator followed by immediate chest compressions, then secure airway

 

The first step in managing ventricular fibrillation  is immediate defibrillation with a single biphasic shock, followed by high-quality chest compressions without delay. Option A is incorrect because epinephrine is not first-line in shockable rhythms and should be given after the second defibrillation cycle. Option C refers to an outdated practice — stacked shocks are no longer recommended. Option D is wrong because synchronized cardioversion is used for organized rhythms like SVT or VT with a pulse, not VF. Prompt defibrillation + CPR is the foundation of VF management in current guidelines.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male mountaineer plans a rapid ascent to an altitude of 4500 meters for a climbing expedition. He has a history of experiencing symptoms like fatigue, non-productive cough, and difficulty breathing during previous high-altitude trips. Based on the scenario, which of the following strategies should the mountaineer implement to effectively prevent symptoms, and what is the main treatment he should consider if symptoms develop?

choices.text: Maintain an average altitude gain exceeding 300 m per day, and begin immediate treatment with acetazolamide
Ascend rapidly without acclimatization, and use supplemental oxygen if symptoms develop
Ascend slowly with a maximum altitude gain of 300 m per day, and prioritize descent of 1000 meters if symptoms occur
Use alcohol to relax during the ascent, and rely solely on portable hyperbaric chambers if symptoms arise

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Ascend slowly with a maximum altitude gain of 300 m per day, and prioritize descent of 1000 meters if symptoms occur

 

The mountaineer is at risk of High Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE) due to rapid ascent and previous symptoms, which include fatigue, cough, and dyspnea. Effective prevention involves a slow ascent with a maximum altitude gain of 300 m per day and the primary treatment for symptoms is immediate descent of 1000 meters to alleviate hypoxia and reduce pulmonary edema.

Maintain an average altitude gain exceeding 300 m per day, and begin immediate treatment with acetazolamide. (Option A): This contradicts the recommendation to limit altitude gain to 300 m per day for prevention, and acetazolamide is not effective for HAPE treatment.

 

Ascend rapidly without acclimatization, and use supplemental oxygen if symptoms develop. (Option B): Rapid ascent increases the risk of HAPE. While supplemental oxygen may help, it is not the primary treatment; immediate descent is crucial.

 

Use alcohol to relax during the ascent, and rely solely on portable hyperbaric chambers if symptoms arise. (Option D): Alcohol should be avoided as it can worsen symptoms. Relying solely on hyperbaric chambers is not recommended without descent as a primary intervention.

High altitude pulmonary edema

Prevention
  • Slow ascent is the most effective method of prevention, even for susceptible individuals.
  • Graded ascent and adequate time for acclimatization.
  • Low sleeping altitudes.
  • Avoidance of alcohol and sleeping pills.
  • Avoidance of vigorous exercise, especially during the first days at altitude.
  • Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, can prevent HAPE in individuals with a history of the condition. The recommended dosage is 60 mg daily of a slow-release formulation, starting during ascent and continuing until the third or fourth day after arrival at the final altitude or after descending below 3000 m.
  • Preliminary data suggest glucocorticoids may prevent HAPE when taken one day prior to ascent and continued during ascent at high altitude.
  • Susceptible individuals should maintain an average altitude gain not exceeding 300 m per day above 2500 m.
  • If progressive acclimatization is not possible, prophylaxis with nifedipine or tadalafil is recommended for long stays at high altitude, and dexamethasone for short stays of less than 5 days.

Treatment
  • The mainstay of treatment is to descend 1000 meters or until symptoms resolve.
  • Minimize exertion during descent to reduce hypoxemia and worsening condition.
  • Oxygen therapy may help alleviate symptoms if descent is delayed or difficult.
  • Main treatment remains descent, regardless of oxygen availability.
  • Supplemental oxygen via high-flow nasal cannula and facemask should be titrated to SpO2 greater than 90%.
  • Portable hyperbaric chambers can be used if descent is not possible but require constant care.
  • Hyperbaric chambers may be challenging for individuals with nausea, vomiting, claustrophobia, or altered mental status from AMS/HACE.
  • There is a risk of symptom recurrence after exiting the hyperbaric chamber.
  • Nifedipine can improve symptoms as an adjunct therapy by reducing pulmonary vasoconstriction.
  • Nifedipine should not be the sole therapy if descent or oxygen is an option.
  • Phosphodiesterase inhibitors may help decrease pulmonary artery and capillary pressure through vasodilation if nifedipine is unavailable.
  • There is no clinically proven role for acetazolamide, β-agonists, or diuretics in the treatment of HAPE.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male skier is found unresponsive in the snow with a core body temperature of 27°C (81°F). Which of the following is NOT a treatment approach for managing his hypothermia?

choices.text: Administer warm intravenous fluids at 40-42°C
Utilize extracorporeal membrane oxygenation to provide rewarming and circulatory support
Use passive external rewarming by layering him with wet clothing
Perform active internal rewarming using warm saline lavage of body cavities

questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Use passive external rewarming by layering him with wet clothing

  • The skier's unresponsiveness and core body temperature of 27°C (81°F) indicate severe hypothermia, defined as a drop in core body temperature below 28°C. This condition disrupts the body's ability to maintain homeostasis, leading to potential organ failure and life-threatening complications.
  • Layering with wet clothing can exacerbate heat loss, as wet materials conduct heat away from the body more efficiently than dry materials. Effective treatment for hypothermia requires removing wet clothing and using dry insulation to help retain body heat.

Treatment of Hypothermia:

  • Initial Management: Focus on rapid rewarming, preventing heat loss, and ensuring airway, breathing, and circulation are managed.
  • Clothing: Remove wet clothing and replace it with dry insulation immediately.
  • Gentle Handling: Move moderate/severe hypothermic patients gently to avoid fatal arrhythmias due to cardiac irritability.
  • Glucose: Administer oral glucose for patients with documented hypoglycemia.

 

Rewarming Techniques:

  1. Passive External Rewarming (for mild hypothermia):
    • Remove wet clothing and apply insulating layers.
    • Shivering aids in heat generation, but requires glucose stores.
    • Rate of rewarming: 0.5 to 2°C per hour.
  2. Active External Rewarming (for moderate to severe hypothermia or refractory mild cases):
    • Use heated air units to reduce heat loss (e.g., warm air blankets).
    • Apply heated packs to axillae, chest, and back.
    • Water immersion (44-45°C) can be used but must be done with care due to risks of cold blood returning to circulation (increased cardiac load).
  3. Active Internal Rewarming (for severe hypothermia):
    • Airway rewarming with humidified warm air.
    • Warm intravenous (IV) fluids (40-42°C). (Option A ruled out)
    • Warm saline lavage of body cavities (e.g., stomach, bladder, colon, peritoneum, pleura). (Option D ruled out)
      • Pleural lavage: Insert two thoracostomy tubes (anterior and posterior) for warm fluid infusion and drainage.
      • Peritoneal lavage: Insert multiple catheters, useful for trauma detection and rewarming.

4. Extracorporeal Rewarming:

  • Hemodialysis: Most accessible, increases core temperature by 2-3°C per hour.
  • Arteriovenous (AV) Rewarming: Warm femoral arterial blood flows to the contralateral femoral vein, raising temperature by 4.5°C per hour.
    • Requires adequate blood pressure.
  • Cardiopulmonary Bypass & ECMO (for cardiac arrest or hemodynamically unstable patients): (Option B ruled out)
    • Most rapid rewarming methods (7-10°C per hour).
    • Provides simultaneous circulatory and oxygenation support.
    • Requires systemic anticoagulation, increasing bleeding risk.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male fisherman is rescued after being exposed to cold water for several hours. Upon examination, his core body temperature is 29°C (84°F). He shows signs of lethargy, dilated pupils, and a slow heart rate. Which of the following statements about his condition is false?

choices.text: Mild hypothermia typically presents with symptoms like shivering and increased muscle tone.
In moderate hypothermia shivering generally stops as the body temperature approaches 30°C.
Severe hypothermia can lead to unresponsiveness and increased risk of cardiac dysrhythmias.
Osborn waves are typically absent in hypothermic patients with temperatures below 28°C.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Osborn waves are typically absent in hypothermic patients with temperatures below 28°C.

Exaplanation:

  • This patient has hypothermia, characterized by a core body temperature of 29°C, leading to symptoms such as lethargy, dilated pupils, and bradycardia. This condition results from prolonged exposure to cold, affecting the body's ability to maintain normal temperature and function.
  • Osborn (J) waves are often present in hypothermic patients and can indicate the severity of the condition.

 

 

J waves seen in ECG

Hypothermia

Definition

Hypothermia is defined as a drop in core body temperature below 35°C, resulting in the failure to maintain homeostasis and affecting all organ systems.

Types
  • Primary Hypothermia: Caused by environmental cold exposure, such as cold air or water. Common in cold geographic areas but can also occur in mild climates.
  • Secondary Hypothermia: Results from conditions that impair heat production or increase heat loss (e.g., trauma, burns, drug overdoses, endocrine disorders, CNS injury, or drug effects).

Clinical Features

Mild Hypothermia (32-35°C / 90-95°F)

(Option A)

  • Symptoms: Hunger, nausea, fatigue, shivering, pale/dry skin, increased muscle tone, blood pressure, heart rate, and respiration.
  • Neurologic symptoms: Cognitive decline, memory impairment, ataxia, dysarthria.
  • Shivering may stop if energy stores are depleted (e.g., malnutrition).
  • Cold-induced diuresis due to peripheral vasoconstriction.

Moderate Hypothermia (28-32°C / 82-90°F)

(Option B)
  • Cognitive decline, lethargy, CNS depression (hyporeflexia, dilated pupils).
  • Shivering stops at 30-32°C.
  • Paradoxical undressing may occur.
  • Increased risk of atrial fibrillation, hypotension, bradycardia, bradypnea.

Severe Hypothermia (<28°C / <82°F)

(Option C)
  • Unresponsiveness, further decline in cerebral blood flow, hypotension, bradycardia, and cardiac output.
  • Risk of atrial, junctional dysrhythmias.
  • Pulmonary congestion, oliguria, and areflexia.
  • Potential for cardiorespiratory failure and death.

ECG Findings
  • Atrial Fibrillation: Most common arrhythmia in hypothermic patients.
  • Bradycardia: Seen in moderate to severe hypothermia, increasing the risk of ventricular arrhythmias.
  • QT Interval Prolongation: Due to slowed impulse conduction through potassium channels.
  • Osborn (J) Waves: Elevated J point, visible on ECG in the precordial leads, with wave height proportional to the degree of hypothermia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male hiker ascends rapidly from sea level to an altitude of 4500 meters over 24 hours. Two days after his arrival, he begins to experience increasing fatigue, a non-productive cough, and difficulty breathing during physical activity. His oxygen saturation is 60% on examination, and he exhibits tachypnea and cyanosis. Based on the scenario, which factors do not contribute to the patient's clinical features?

choices.text: Low hypoxic ventilatory response (HVR)
Use of sleep medications during ascent
Recent heavy physical exertion prior to ascent
Extended acclimatization period before ascent

questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Extended acclimatization period before ascent

  • The patient’s symptoms, including fatigue, cough, tachypnea, and low oxygen saturation, are characteristic of acute HAPE, a severe form of altitude sickness resulting from hypoxia and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema.
  • An extended acclimatization period is protective against altitude sickness. It allows the body to adjust to lower oxygen levels gradually, thereby reducing the risk of developing HAPE (High altitude pulmonary edema).

Low hypoxic ventilatory response (Option A): A low HVR is a significant risk factor for developing altitude-related illnesses, including HAPE. It impairs the body's ability to respond to low oxygen levels, making it more likely for the patient to experience severe hypoxia and associated symptoms.

 

Use of sleep medications during ascent (Option B): Sleep medications can depress the respiratory drive, leading to a reduced HVR. This can worsen hypoxia at high altitudes, increasing the risk of HAPE and contributing to the patient's clinical features.

 

Recent heavy physical exertion prior to ascent (Option C): Engaging in heavy physical exertion can lead to fatigue and increased susceptibility to altitude sickness, including HAPE. This factor can contribute to the worsening of symptoms once at high altitude.

High altitude pulmonary edema

About
  • HAPE is a severe, high-altitude illness, potentially fatal.
  • It is noncardiogenic pulmonary edema caused by hypoxia.
  • It occurs above 2500 meters, and can start as low as 2000 meters.
  • Risk factors: low hypoxic ventilatory response (HVR), rapid ascent, male sex, sleep medications, high salt intake, cold temperatures, and heavy exertion.
  • Pre-existing conditions (e.g., pulmonary hypertension) increase risk.
  • Faster ascent correlates with higher incidence.

Pathophysiology
  • HAPE results from the pulmonary vasculature's response to hypoxia.
  • Hypoxic ventilatory response (HVR) varies among individuals and has a genetic component.
  • High altitude adaptations include changes in resting ventilation, HVR, oxygen saturation, and hemoglobin concentration.
  • Rapid ascent to altitude causes immediate increases in minute ventilation and respiratory alkalosis.
  • Shifts in the oxygen-dissociation curve occur, initially increasing oxygen affinity, followed by a decrease as 2,3-DPG levels rise.
  • Blunted HVR (due to genetic factors or sedatives) leads to exaggerated hypoxemic pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV).
  • HPV increases perfusion to affected alveoli, raising capillary pressures and permeability, leading to non-uniform pulmonary edema.
  • This edema further impedes oxygen transport and exacerbates pulmonary hypertension.

Clinical features
  • HAPE typically manifests 2 to 5 days after arriving at high altitude.
  • Initial symptoms include non-productive cough, decreased exercise tolerance, chest pain, and exertional dyspnea.
  • Progression can lead to dyspnea at rest, productive cough with pink frothy sputum, rales, and cyanosis.
  • Patients may exhibit tachypnea and tachycardia.
  • SpO2 levels are often significantly lower than expected for altitude, with values typically ranging from 40% to 70%.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, 36 weeks pregnant, is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at home. Upon arrival, she is unresponsive and in cardiac arrest. CPR is initiated immediately. The team begins advanced cardiac life support for pregnancy. Which of the following is the correct to optimize maternal and fetal outcomes?

choices.text: Delay chest compressions to position the patient for cesarean section.
Perform left uterine displacement.
Administer 2 mg epinephrine IV every 5 minutes.
Delay defibrillation to avoid harm to the fetus.

questions.solution:
Relieving aortocaval compression is essential to improve venous return and cardiac output. Left uterine displacement (LUD) is crucial in pregnancy to optimize maternal resuscitation efforts.

 

Cardiac Arrest in Pregnancy

Mnemonic

Causes of maternal cardiac arrest

A

Anesthetic Complications (Aspiration, High neuraxial block, Respiratory depression)

Accidents/ Trauma

B

Bleeding (Uterine atony, Placenta accreta, Abruption, Uterine rupture)

C

Cardiovascular Causes (MI, Cardiomyopathy, Valve disease, Congenital heart disease)

D

Drug-Related Issues (Oxytocin, Opioids, Illicit drugs, Anaphylaxis)

E

Embolic Causes (Amniotic fluid, Pulmonary, Venous air embolism)

F

Fever (Sepsis, Infection)

G

General Issues - H’s and T’s (causes of cardiac arrest)

H

Hypertension (Preeclampsia, Eclampsia, HELLP syndrome)


 

Cardiac Arrest Management in Pregnancy

  1. Place the patient in a full left lateral decubitus position to relieve aortocaval compression.
  2. Administer 100% oxygen via face mask to treat or prevent hypoxemia.
  3. Establish intravenous access above the diaphragm to prevent obstruction by the gravid uterus.
  4. Identify and treat any precipitating factors contributing to cardiac arrest.
  5. A pregnant patient with in-hospital cardiac arrest should not be transported for cesarean delivery. Management should occur at the site of the arrest. (Option A ruled out)
  6. Immediately perform chest compressions (CPR) at a rate of at least 100 per minute, with a depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm), allowing full recoil.
  7. Limit interruptions to 10 seconds, except for advanced airway placement or defibrillation.
  8. Continuously perform manual left uterine displacement (LUD) if the uterus is palpated at or above the umbilicus.
  9. Use the same defibrillation protocol as in nonpregnant patients, applying biphasic shocks of 120 to 200 J, escalating if necessary. (Option D ruled out)
  10. For refractory ventricular fibrillation or tachycardia, administer amiodarone 300 mg rapid infusion, with 150 mg doses as needed.
  11. Consider administering 1 mg epinephrine IV/IO every 3 to 5 minutes during cardiac arrest; it is preferred over vasopressin. (Option C ruled out)
  12. If maternal resuscitation fails, consider a cesarean section if the gestational age is greater than 23 weeks, ideally performed within 4 minutes after maternal arrest to maximize fetal survival.
  13. Fetal Survival: The earlier the fetus is delivered following maternal arrest, the better the chances of survival, with the best outcomes if delivered within 5 minutes of CPR initiation.

 

Supine Hypotensive syndrome

  • Supine hypotensive syndrome occurs in late pregnancy (usually after 20 weeks) due to the gravid uterus compressing the inferior vena cava and aorta when a pregnant woman lies on her back, leading to maternal hypotension.
  • Treatment involves repositioning the patient to alleviate compression, either by turning her onto her left side or manually displacing the uterus if spine immobilization is needed.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man suffers a witnessed cardiac arrest in the emergency room. After 3 cycles of CPR , iv epinephrine, 2 defibrillation shocks, he achieves return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). He is now unresponsive, with a blood pressure of 88/50 mmHg and SpO₂ of 92% on 10 L/min oxygen by face mask. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer 1 mg epinephrine IV every 3–5 minutes and continue chest compressions
Perform immediate coronary angiography and stenting regardless of ECG findings
Optimize oxygenation and ventilation, and assess for need of vasopressors and targeted temperature management
Discontinue resuscitation efforts and observe, as ROSC has been achieved

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Optimize oxygenation and ventilation, and assess for need of vasopressors and targeted temperature management

Once ROSC is achieved, the next priority is post-cardiac arrest care, which includes ensuring adequate oxygenation (SpO₂ >94%), avoiding hyperoxia, supporting blood pressure (e.g., fluids, vasopressors if MAP <65 mmHg), and considering targeted temperature management (TTM) if the patient is comatose. Option A is incorrect because epinephrine and CPR are no longer indicated after ROSC. Option B is premature unless STEMI is evident on ECG. Option D ignores the fact that ROSC patients remain critically ill and need intensive support. Thus, Option C reflects the AHA compliant post-ROSC bundle.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man experiences a sudden cardiac arrest while jogging in a park. A bystander witnesses the collapse. According to the Adult OHCA Chain of Survival, what is the correct sequence of actions performed by the emergency responders in this scenario?

choices.text: Early recognition and Prevention → Activation of Emergency Response → Defibrillation → High-Quality CPR → Recovery→ Post-Cardiac Arrest Care
Activation of Emergency Response → High-Quality CPR → Defibrillation → Advanced Resuscitation → Post-Cardiac Arrest Care → Recovery
High-Quality CPR → Activation of Emergency Response → Advanced Resuscitation → Defibrillation → Post-Cardiac Arrest Care → Recovery
High-Quality CPR → Activation of Emergency Response → Defibrillation → Advanced Resuscitation → Post-Cardiac Arrest Care → Recovery

questions.solution:
The Adult OHCA (Out-of-Hospital Cardiac Arrest) Chain of Survival mnemonic : All Cool Doctors Are Perfect Rescuers 

Activate EMS 

CPR 

Defibrillate 

Advanced resuscitation 

Post cardiac care 

Recovery and Rehabililation 

 

IHCA- In-hospital cardiac arrest; OHCA- Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest

Option A, C & D are incorrect orders of OHCA.

questions.text: 4-year-old child is found unresponsive at home. The parents initiate CPR, and the child is transported to the emergency department. Upon arrival, the medical team begins CPR and attaches a defibrillator. The rhythm check shows asystole. What is the next step in managing this child according to the Pediatric cardiac arrest Algorithm?

choices.text: Deliver a shock immediately
Administer Amiodarone IV/IO
Administer Epinephrine and continue CPR
Administer Lidocaine IV/IO

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Administer Epinephrine and continue CPR

 

  • In the pediatric cardiac arrest algorithm (Step 9), asystole is a non-shockable rhythm. The appropriate treatment involves continuing CPR and administering Epinephrine as soon as possible (Step 10).
  • Amiodarone: Used in VF/pVT. Begin with 300 mg IV/IO; a follow-up dose of 150 mg IV/IO may be administered if needed. An alternative dose is 5 mg/kg IV.
  • Lidocaine: Used in VF/pVT. Start with 1-1.5 mg/kg IV. If ventricular fibrillation (VF) or pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT) persists, administer 0.5-0.75 mg/kg IV every 5-10 minutes, up to a maximum of 3 mg/kg.

 

Defibrillation (shock) (Option A) is not indicated for asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA), which are non-shockable rhythms.

 

Medications such as Amiodarone and Lidocaine (Option B & D) are used for shockable rhythms like ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia, not for asystole.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about massive transfusion is not correct?

choices.text: PRBC should be administered first to address hypoxia and acidosis in bleeding patient
1:1:0.25 ratio of PRBC: FFP: SDP
Blood products should be warmed before infusion to prevent coaguloapthy
ABO grouping is not required for platelet transfusion

questions.solution:
Answer is D: ABO grouping is not required for platelet transfusion

Even in massive transfusion, ABO grouping for platelets is relevant and preferred. The statement “ABO matching is not required” is still incorrect, although relaxed in emergencies under strict protocols.

In the massive transfusion protocol, PRBC must be administered first because, in a bleeding patient, blood loss causes hypoxia and acidosis. PRBC carries oxygen and helps neutralize the acidosis component.. Platelets should not be given first as their function would be impaired by acidosis.

The ratio of PRBC:FFP: PRP should be maintained at 1:1:1, but for SDP is 1:1: 0.25. 

Warming of blood products is essential during rapid transfusion to prevent hypothermia, which is a significant risk in trauma patients receiving large volumes of cold blood products. Hypothermia can lead to coagulopathy, worsening the bleeding.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer is brought to ER 2 hours after being bitten by a snake on his left ankle. He has severe swelling of the left leg, gingival bleeding, and incoagulable blood on the 20-minute whole blood clotting time test. You decide to administer ASV . Twenty minutes after starting the ASV infusion, the patient develops urticaria, cough, and abdominal pain. His blood pressure drops to 85/50 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue ASV infusion permanently
Continue ASV infusion and administer corticosteroids
Stop ASV infusion temporarily and treat with epinephrine
Administer heparin to counteract coagulopathy

questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Stop ASV infusion temporarily and treat with epinephrine

In this case, the patient is developing an early (anaphylactic) reaction to the ASV, which occurs within 10-180 minutes of starting treatment. The symptoms presented (urticaria, cough, abdominal pain, and hypotension) are typical of this reaction.

The correct management for an early ASV reaction is as follows:

  1. Stop the ASV infusion immediately.
  2. Administer epinephrine (adrenaline) intramuscularly or subcutaneously.
  3. Give antihistamines and corticosteroids.
  4. Treat shock if present (IV fluids, oxygen).
  5. Once symptoms have subsided, resume ASV administration at a slower rate.

 

ASV Complications and Management

Complication

Timing

Symptoms

Management

Early (Anaphylactic) Reaction

10-180 minutes after starting ASV

- Itching, urticaria

- Nausea, vomiting

- Cough, abdominal colic

- Fever, tachycardia

- Hypotension

- Bronchospasm

- Angioedema

1. Stop ASV infusion immediately

2. Administer epinephrine (adrenaline) IM or SC

3. Give antihistamines and corticosteroids

4. Treat shock if present

5. Resume ASV at a slower rate after symptoms subside

Pyrogenic Reaction

1-2 hours after treatment

- Fever

- Rigors

- Hypotension

- Symptomatic treatment

- Antipyretics

- IV fluids if needed

Late (Serum Sickness) Reaction

5-24 days (mean 7 days) after ASV

- Fever

- Itching

- Urticaria

- Arthralgia

- Lymphadenopathy

- Proteinuria

- Antihistamines

- Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) for 5-7 days

 

Discontinue ASV infusion permanently (Option A) is incorrect because ASV is crucial for treating severe envenomation. After managing the reaction, ASV should be restarted.

 

Continuing ASV infusion and administering corticosteroids (Option B) is incorrect because continuing the infusion during an anaphylactic reaction can worsen the patient's condition. The infusion should be stopped first.

 

Administer heparin (Option D) is incorrect and potentially dangerous. Heparin is contraindicated in snake bite-induced coagulopathy and would not address the anaphylactic reaction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old farmer is brought to the ER 30 minutes after being bitten by a snake on his right leg. He presents with severe pain and swelling at the bite site, and examination reveals two puncture wounds. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg and he has gingival bleeding. The 20-minute whole blood clotting time test shows that the blood is incoagulable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer crypoprecipitate
Administer 150-200 ml of polyvalent antivenom
Apply a tight tourniquet above the bite site
Administer heparin to manage coagulopathy

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Administer 150-200 ml of polyvalent antivenom

In this case, the patient shows signs of severe envenomation:

  1. Severe pain and swelling at the bite site
  2. Hypotension (BP 90/60 mmHg)
  3. Gingival bleeding
  4. Incoagulable blood on the 20-minute whole blood clotting time test
  • These symptoms strongly suggest a viper bite with significant systemic effects.
  • According to the management guide, for severe poisoning with rapidly progressive or overt haemolysis or coagulopathy, the recommended antivenom dose is 150-200 ml.

 

Management of Snakebite

Management

Details

Indications/Notes

First Aid

-Do not allow the victim to walk (Carry)

-Avoid tourniquets, except in specific cases(No)

- Reassure patient

- Immobilize bitten limb

- Transport to the hospital quickly

- Tell the doctor about any systemic symptoms

Tourniquets only for severe elapid/sea snake bites with >0.5h but <2-3h transport time

Evaluation

- Check for signs of envenomation

- Monitor vital signs

- Perform 20-minute whole blood clotting time

- Check coagulation profile, CPK, renal function

Incoagulable blood indicates systemic envenomation by Viperidae

Antivenom Therapy

- Mild: 50 ml

- Moderate: 50-100 ml

- Severe: 150-200 ml

Effective against the 4 most important venomous snakes in India, namely, Cobra, Common Krait, Russell's viper and saw-scaled viper.

Indications:

- Haemostatic abnormalities

- Neurotoxicity

- Cardiovascular dysfunction

- Impaired consciousness

- Rhabdomyolysis

- Extensive local swelling

Antivenom Administration

- Dilute in 5 ml/kg body weight of isotonic saline/5% Dextrose

- Infuse over 1-2 hours

- Monitor for hypersensitivity reactions

Repeat if severe signs persist after 1-2 hours or if coagulability is not restored within 6 hours

Supportive Care

- Tetanus prophylaxis

- Antibiotics (if severe local reaction)

- Manage respiratory paralysis

- Fresh frozen plasma/cryoprecipitates for severe bleeding

Avoid heparin, corticosteroids, and EDTA.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department after being bitten by a snake while working in his field in rural India. He presents with severe local pain, swelling, and gum bleeding. Within 2 hours, he develops diplopia, dysphagia, and progressive weakness in his limbs. Laboratory tests show prolonged prothrombin time and decreased fibrinogen levels.

Which of the following snakes is most likely responsible for this envenomation?

choices.text: Cobra
Russell's viper
Saw-scaled viper
Krait

questions.solution:
Correct answer- B) Russell's viper

The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a combination of hemotoxic and neurotoxic effects:

  1. Hemotoxic: Severe local pain and swelling, gum bleeding, prolonged prothrombin time, and decreased fibrinogen levels.
  2. Neurotoxic: Diplopia, dysphagia, and progressive limb weakness.

This combination of hemotoxic and neurotoxic effects is characteristic of Russell's viper envenomation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with sepsis secondary to a urinary tract infection. After 48 hours, she develops acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. Her chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates, and her PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 180 mmHg on PEEP of 8 cm H2O. An echocardiogram shows normal cardiac function. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate high-frequency oscillatory ventilation
Start inhaled nitric oxide therapy
Begin low tidal volume ventilation with 6 mL/kg lean body weight
Administer high-dose corticosteroids

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Begin low tidal volume ventilation with 6 mL/kg predicted body weight

The patient meets the Berlin criteria for ARDS:

  • Timing: Within 1 week of known clinical insult (sepsis)
  • Chest imaging: Bilateral infiltrates
  • Origin of edema: Not due to cardiac failure (confirmed by echocardiogram)
  • Oxygenation: PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 180 mmHg (indicating moderate ARDS: 100 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 200 mmHg)

For moderate ARDS, the next best management option is low tidal volume ventilation with a predicted body weight of 6 mL/kg.

 

ARDS: Diagnosis and Management

Diagnosis (Berlin Definition)

Timing

Within 1 week of known clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms

Chest Imaging

Bilateral opacities not fully explained by effusions, collapse, or nodules

Origin of Edema

Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload

Oxygenation
  • Mild (Grade A): 200 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg (with PEEP or CPAP ≥ 5 cm H2O)
  • Moderate (Grade B): 100 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 200 mmHg
  • Severe (Grade C & D): PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 100 mmHg

Management Recommendations

Grade A (Mild)
  • Low tidal volume ventilation (4–8 ml/kg predicted body weight) and lower inspiratory pressures (plateau pressure < 30 cm H2O)

Grade B (Moderate)
  • Minimized plateau and driving pressures
  • High PEEP (35–50 cmH2O for 20–40 s)
  • Prone positioning
  • Recruitment maneuvers
  • ECMO in selected patients

Grade C (Severe)
  • Neuromuscular blockade in early ARDS
  • Conservative fluid management
  • Inhaled vasodilators as rescue therapy
  • Avoid routine use of pulmonary artery catheter

Grade D (Severe)
  • Avoid high-frequency oscillatory ventilation
  • Avoid β2-agonists for improving outcomes

 

High-frequency oscillatory ventilation (Option A): Not recommended for routine use in ARDS. May be harmful in some patients.

 

Inhaled nitric oxide (Option B): It is a Grade C recommendation- considered as rescue therapy in patients with severe hypoxemia. It may temporarily improve oxygenation.

 

High-dose corticosteroids (Option D): Not specifically recommended in early ARDS

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with severe pneumonia. He develops worsening respiratory symptoms and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray within 5 days. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism occurring in the alveoli during the early phase of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Increased surfactant production
Thickening of the alveolar basement membrane
Accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid
Fibrosis of the alveolar walls

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid

Such kind of fast deterioation in a case of pneumonia indicates development of acute respiratory distress syndrome. The key pathophysiological mechanism in the early exudative phase of ARDS accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid. This occurs due to increased capillary permeability resulting from injury to the alveolar-capillary membrane.

 

ARDS: Causes and Pathophysiology

Category

Details

Direct Lung Injury Causes
  • Pneumonia
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • Pulmonary contusion
  • Near-drowning
  • Toxic inhalation injury

Indirect Lung Injury Causes
  • Sepsis
  • Severe trauma
  • Multiple bone fractures
  • Pancreatitis
  • Burns
  • Multiple transfusions
  • Drug overdose
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass
Pathophysiology
  • Exudative Phase (0-7 days):

- Injury to alveolar capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes

- Increased capillary permeability

- Accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid in alveoli and interstitium

- Formation of hyaline membranes

- Neutrophil infiltration and activation

- Release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α, IL-1, IL-8)

- Impaired gas exchange and reduced lung compliance

  • Proliferative Phase (7-21 days):

- Proliferation of type II pneumocytes

- Resolution of alveolar edema

- Early fibroproliferation

  • Fibrotic Phase (>21 days):

- Collagen deposition and fibrosis in some patients

 

Increased surfactant production (Option A): ARDS leads to reduced surfactant dysfunction, not increased production.

 

Thickening of the alveolar basement membrane (Option B): While this may occur later in ARDS, it's not a primary mechanism in the early phase. This is also seen in bronchial asthma. 

 

Fibrosis of the alveolar walls (Option D): This is a feature of the late (fibrotic) phase of ARDS, not the early phase.

questions.text:
A 55 year-old male presents to the emergency department with fever, tachypnea, and altered mental status. BP is 100/60 mm Hg 

Laboratory results show:


	WBC: 14,000/μL
	Serum lactate: 1.8 mmol/L
	Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL)


Chest X-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate. The patient requires 6 L/min of oxygen to maintain  pO2 of 90 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most accurate diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome
Sepsis
Acute Tubular necrosis
Septic shock

questions.solution:
Answer is B: Sepsis 

According to the Sepsis-3 criteria , sepsis is defined as a life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection. The clinical criteria for sepsis include:

  1. Suspected infection
  2. An acute increase of ≥2  point in SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment)  

In this case:

  • The patient has a suspected lung infection (fever and chest X-ray infiltrate).
  • There is evidence of organ dysfunction:
    • Respiratory: PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 200 . PaO₂ = 90 mm Hg

    • Oxygen flow rate = 6 L/min via nasal cannula

    • Estimated FiO₂ at 6 L/min ≈ 45% = 0.45

    • so PaO2/FiO2= 90/0.45 = 200 

    • Renal: Creatinine increase > 0.3 mg/dL from baseline

This meets the Sepsis-3 criteria for sepsis.

 

SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) Score:

The SOFA score is a more comprehensive tool used to assess organ dysfunction in potentially septic patients. It evaluates six organ systems:

  1. Respiratory (PaO2/FiO2 ratio)
  2. Cardiovascular (Mean arterial pressure and vasopressor requirements)
  3. Hepatic (Bilirubin level)
  4. Coagulation (Platelet count)
  5. Renal (Creatinine level or urine output)
  6. Neurological (Glasgow Coma Scale)

Each system is scored from 0 to 4, with higher scores indicating more severe dysfunction. A total SOFA score ranges from 0 to 24.

questions.text: A 30-year-old trauma patient underwent massive transfusion protocol after a road traffic accident. Six hours later, he develops acute onset dyspnea, hypoxia, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray. He is afebrile, Pulse 100/min with BP 124/ 80 mm Hg. JVP is normal and pro NT BNP levels are normal.  What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload
Transfusion-related acute lung injury
Mismatched blood transfusion
Laryngospasm due to citrate induced hypocalcemia

questions.solution:
Answer is B: Transfusion-related acute lung injury

Since BP is normal , neck veins are not distended and Pro-NT-BNP levels are normal it indicates TRALI developing after blood transfusion. 

Differences between Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury and TACO 

Feature

Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury

Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload 

Definition

Acute non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema following blood transfusion.

Acute pulmonary edema due to volume overload from blood transfusion.

Onset

Usually within 6 hours of transfusion.

Can occur during or up to 12 hours post-transfusion.

Pathophysiology

Immune-mediated injury to pulmonary capillaries leads to fluid leakage into alveoli.

Volume overload causes increased hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary circulation.

Symptoms

Sudden onset of dyspnea, hypoxemia, fever, hypotension.

Dyspnea, orthopnea, rapid weight gain, hypertension.

Physical Findings

Crackles, tachypnea, no signs of fluid overload (e.g., jugular venous distension).

Crackles, tachypnea, signs of fluid overload (e.g., elevated JVP, peripheral edema).

Blood Pressure

Hypotensive or normal.

Hypertensive.

Laboratory Findings

Neutrophilia, leukocytosis, and anti-HLA antibodies in donor blood (in some cases).

Elevated BNP (brain natriuretic peptide), no specific markers for TACO.

Treatment

Supportive care (oxygen, mechanical ventilation if necessary), no diuretics.

Diuretics (e.g., furosemide), oxygen, stopping or slowing the transfusion.

Prevention

Use of leukocyte-reduced or HLA-matched blood products.

Slow transfusion rate, avoid excess volume, and monitor for fluid overload.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the trauma center following a motorcycle accident. He is unconscious BP 70/40 mmHg and shows signs of active bleeding. Massive transfusion protocol is initiated. After receiving 4 units of PRBCs rapidly, he develops muscle twitching. ABG shows metabolic alkalosis. ECG shows normal sinus rythm with QT prolongation. What is the most appropriate immediate next step in his management?

choices.text: Administer intravenous calcium gluconate to correct citrate-induced hypocalcemia, which is causing neuromuscular irritability and QT prolongation.
Start platelet transfusion immediately to correct dilutional thrombocytopenia, as prolonged transfusion leads to bleeding due to thrombocytopenia.
Give sodium bicarbonate to treat the developing metabolic alkalosis resulting from massive transfusion.
Transfuse cryoprecipitate to correct fibrinogen deficiency and prevent DIC-like picture often seen after >10 units of PRBC.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A: Administer intravenous calcium gluconate to correct citrate-induced hypocalcemia, which is causing neuromuscular irritability and QT prolongation

After rapid transfusion of multiple units of PRBCs, citrate toxicity can occur, leading to hypocalcemia, which presents with muscle twitching, paresthesias, and prolonged QT interval — hence, IV calcium gluconate is the most immediate and appropriate step. Option B is important later in MTP but not the priority here, as the clinical picture points toward electrolyte imbalance, not active coagulopathy. Option C is incorrect because metabolic alkalosis seen post-transfusion is usually mild and self-limiting due to metabolism of citrate to bicarbonate; treating it with sodium bicarbonate can worsen alkalosis and is not first-line. Option D, while relevant in ongoing transfusions, is not the immediate response to the described ECG and
